But if you go to the retailer, the chains that are buying products from us, then you see a different picture. Of course, the lower end brands and the middle range brands where you need to invest less money to buy stock, they are more open to buy because they are less scared to sit on stock, that's very expensive and they hear everywhere that luxury is in a crisis.

So the retailer was and is in some areas still reluctant to take the expensive pieces. And here you have a difference. The very high-end prestige, they have, for example, in Hong Kong a big problem to sell into the retailer, but the sell-out in the own stores showed that the demand is still there. And here you have a clear difference between the very prestigious high-end Breguet Blancpain, Glashütte to the rest and if I take Omega, also Omega had with the gold watches and the very high-end watches, we felt that the retailer is reluctant because he is scared to block too much of his money. However in the own stores, we have seen that also the high-end pieces are flowing out very well, so this is the difference.

But it's fair to say that you have suffered in the first half year also from a negative mix effect i.e. that – on the back that your lower price segments has performed better, this – on average lower margins, that your margins was negatively affected through that?

I don't know, if you can say it that way. I would say we have – I mean, if we do 15% less turnover, we have suffered, if you want, so I agree with you. And if we do less profit we have suffered, it's relative but okay, we have suffered. But the problem is the selling pattern of the retailer it's not a sell-out if I talk about our product. You see it's an – the problem is that cash was not available for whatever reason. I don't want to elaborate. Many retailers were reluctant or could not buy the stock they need to make the sales and with expensive products it's more difficult.
Okay.

But again, I told you, June, July, August is just changing the pattern. The retailers need now the product because they are short of product, they are short of product that the consumer is asking for and especially if you have brands that are doing investment in marketing that has new product they need these product because otherwise the consumer doesn't go to them, he comes to our own source.

What is the risk that this a whole reaction of the retailers that they just do now the stock resetting, that you have for a couple of months relatively good sales to the retailers. But that then the underlying demand is not coming back, let's say, first half year 2010 do you see this risk?

Oh my God. If I look at the numbers, I can tell you the demand is already back in the second half of 2009. I mean, if I look at the number you are still – do a paradigm shift. We are back, the demand is there. There is no exaggeration, you cannot expect 30% increases. But the demand for the product is there, the stocks have come down but the demand is there. Even in the U.S., it goes again up. And in 2010, I see no reason at all, why we should not have a better situation then at the beginning of 2009. I see no reason. All signals I see are rather going into an improvement and it's the consumer who tells me this. He continues to spend money on all segments and all levels.

Of course, he is more careful when he buys, what he buys and if it is quality. And we have to tell him this and we have to support the consumer for his choice. And actually no reason, I'm optimistic, I was optimistic at the beginning of the year and I'm still optimistic and I will be even still more optimistic for 2010. I don't see any reason why we should go into a situation that would be worse. Do you see any signals?
Well, at the moment, I see it is going up there, but who knows for 2010.
You see I must really put the finger on what we said at the beginning of the year. You were all a little bit looking at us that we are poor guys. But we have the information from the markets.

We know the consumer, his behavior and we can judge more or less why he is doing what, we cannot predict in percentages what will happen exactly. But we are here and paid for to do the necessary stuffs to gain this consumer confidence and to sell-in our products.
And all the conditions are met in distribution, in product, in communication, and also in consumer mood to improve the situation in 2009 already but also in 2010.

There is no reason for us to see any negative signal at the horizon. We see opportunities as I said before; the U.S. has now the big chance to learn distribution in watches from some other countries in the world, who went that step. And I think this will give us a big boost in the United States for 2010.
Okay. Thank you.
Next question.
Next question is from Mr. Thomas Chauvet from Citigroup. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi. Good afternoon. Most of my questions have been asked. Maybe one on production, can you, Mr. Hayek, tell us the recent developments in the previous proposals for a change in the Swiss-made definition? Do you think this will be implemented when and could that impact significantly your production division's output and of course margins?

Listen, we are still discussing this on the level of the Fédération horlogère, but we are all of the opinion, it's important in the interest of the consumer that the Swiss-made must be reinforced in the interest of the consumer. I say it again; the consumer has the right, because he pays a premium for Swiss-made products. And he must know what does it mean Swiss-made and the reinforcement of the Swiss-made is a benefit for the whole Swiss watch industry, for the small entrepreneur as well as the big one. And all the big groups are in agreement that we should move forward to improve the situation, it's really important for the consumer. Mr. Kenel wants to say something.

Yes, about the Swiss made, it's not only a question about decision of the watch industry or the Fédération horlogère, it's also about a political question on the European level, because this question has to be accepted by the other countries too. If we are going out with a Swiss-made, then a country like Germany or England has to accept that and this is not yet done and the decision is still open, so it's not up to us to do that.

I heard that our government, the governments of the other countries, they had a headache because of the financial industry recently. And they are so occupied to try to get this financial industry back on track, so they had no time to take care of that. But I hope this will soon be done and the whole mess will be cleaned up, so we can start again to do the business for the industry.
Okay. Thank you.
You're welcome. Okay. We have the last, who is it, Thomas Chauvet, yes.
No.
Oh. So the next last three ones.
Next question is from Ms. Louise Singlehurst from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead, madam.

Hi. Good afternoon. You talked quite a bit about the retail expansion. Is there a bigger plan if we look more long-term over the next five years to significantly increase that as a proportion? And just sticking with the wholesale scene, when do you expect to get the first indications from wholesalers for Christmas orders? Is that really September onwards? And then lastly, just specifically on mainland China, there's been a bit of news very recently on the plan – or the potential plan that China might reduce the level of import taxes on luxury goods. Do you think that's likely done over the medium term?

Louise, yes. The tax issue we are pleading since a long time. It would be good if they reduce the taxes. We heard about these plans and we will see what's happening when they are in place. It will only be a benefit for all of us. So we can live with what is today, but we can very good live with what is happening if they do a reduction in taxes. By the way, it would be good for Russia, it would be good for India.
Brazil.

Brazil. We have many countries where an initiative like this would be very helpful. So we can cope with it and we can also cope with it if it is not happening. Then on the retail level, Swatch, depending on the country, the brand Swatch, in the U.S., Swatch is doing practically 90% of the turnover in own stores, very successfully. In other areas and countries, Swatch is about 20% or 10% only in own stores. But I think it's fair to say, the brand Swatch can be between 50 to 60% sold in own stores long-term.
Yes.
So this is for the brand Swatch?
Yes.

I could even think it could be more than this. Then if you come to a brand like Breguet, or Blancpain, the high-end mono brands, I think it's fair to say that they could perhaps in five years sell 30 to 40% through own stores. It could be possible, depends on the country and on legislation. You have some countries that don't allow you to own your stores, and then you have a problem. But it could be around 30 to 40%. With Omega, I think the maximum we could face in own stores or our franchise stores would be around 20%. I don't think much more, perhaps 20, 25, but I don't think it's necessary and useful to have more.

And then, we have the multi-brand concepts, the Tourbillon stores. Here, we are at about 18. We'll not have a big expansion of this one. However, the travel retail, we have our own company, Tech-Airport, that is operating only Charles de Gaulle in France and Nice, and we won the tender for a watch department with a mono-brand store of Omega at the Geneva Airport that will open in November. And this company will make expansion, because there is big potential for travel retail, watch specialists. And here, we will probably see that in the travel retail, we could increase. Today, we do very small amounts in travel retail through our own company, but here we could do probably more in the future. So that's more or less the percentages retail of our Group.
Great. Thank you very much.
You're welcome. Now I think we are through.
The next question is a follow-up question from Mr. John Guy from MF Global Securities. Please go ahead, sir.
Okay. We'll let him. We'll have two more, and then we are exhausted.

Well, thank you. Thank you very much. I was just looking at the fixed and variable cost base for the watches and jewelry segment. And would you agree that you have an advantage at the moment in having a lower fixed cost base because of your high exposure to third-party distribution?

And within the variable cost base, you have the capacity to be a little bit more aggressive in terms of advertising and promotion cuts, if you need to. It seems in the first half of the year, you haven't really taken very aggressive steps to make those cuts. But should there be a – well, an unexpected downturn in the second half, based on your comments so far, would you take the necessary action to cut your advertising spend, A&P promotion and marketing by anywhere between two and 300 million?

There are many measures you can take before that you attack marketing or research and development. Get many fields where we can save money before that you do these steps. Of course, we are monitoring, if there is a worldwide terrible crisis and sales are going down to zero, we'll certainly reduce the marketing expenses in this area. But again, we are very cautious. It's ongoing, we are monitoring every week, every month our numbers.

We are looking where we can save money, and we have many, many places where we can save money before that we are attacking it. And of course, we try to have more marketing visible and spending less for it, that's important. We are not trying to throw the money out of the window. But what we need to give as the signal is we believing in the marketplace, it's developing and we see it, the sell out is positive. Now what you said, that we have a fixed cost advantage because we deliver to third parties.
No, I was saying that your fixed and variable cost relationship is more 50/50, Richmond's fixed cost base might be a little bit higher, around 70%.
But Richmond is not producing anything.
I know.
Richmond is taking advantage of the Swatch Group, they leave us with all the cost, no, but this is true. They – all the movements, components from us. This is reality. It's a truth.
Yeah. I know.

It's a truth. When you ask them last year or two years ago, they could tell what is the evidence Swatch could not deliver us as of much as we wanted. It's a reality. They take advantage of us. They take advantage of our investment, of our money. This is the reality. We don't take advantage from them, it's the contrary. They take advantage from us, from our innovation, from our strength. Look at what is in their product as a base, it's our moments. It's our components. Jesus Christ. You get me angry now.
I didn't mean to see that?

No, I know, but this is the reality. And we have also sense of responsibility. We keep our factories open. We continue to invest despite the fact that these people taking the phone and say, hey, guys, we call next year again, if we need something. Now we don't need anything anymore, ciao. That's an approach – that's a finance approach, not an entrepreneur approach. Okay, that's – not want to elaborate more about that.
Thank you very much.
Thank you. Bye. Mr. Eifert?
The next question is from Mr. Matthias Eifert from MainFirst Bank. Please go ahead, sir.
Yeah. Thanks for taking...
You have the – always you have the last question.

That is great. Thanks to hear that. And actually I wanted to turn this around and answer your question and what I was referring to before when I asked you what has changed since March because I looked at your press release from March and you said that you expect modest growth in 2009 over 2008.

Now you're saying you expect a stable sales in the second half compared to the second half last year. And if I add the development in the first half, I get to something like minus 8.7% sales in 2009, therefore I was asking you what has changed since March?
I ask you what has changed since March?
Yeah. What did get worse since March that you now guide us a bit lower on sales?

No, it's not worse. We said in May that we would try to achieve the same thing. You are taking the papers, you're reading them. We have some careful statements in there and we will say, look, the second – yes, I repeat it for the 250 times. So, one thing that has certainly not changed is the approach of the analyst questions, they are always the same.

So let me come back to this. We in March said our objective is still to be as close as possible in the watch business as we have been in 2008 in local currency. Now, we have the result, we have minus 15 or 16. We didn't have the minus 15 in March. What did you have, did you think that we fixed it already? As you think also that we put in our stores the turnover and the stock and we sell it already.

So what has changed that we have the results now? We have the results for the first half-year, and then we say, okay, what will be the second half? We can write in our paper, yes, the second half will be outperforming 20% more than in 2008. We say, guys, we'd expect that there will be a possibility of growth in the second half.

And I said it before, I think three times, it depends on November-December. If November-December is outstanding, what could be, we will of course reach what we said in March. So nothing has changed in the objective of the group. We're just formulating a little bit careful and we saw that this is very positive to say that the second half of the year is flat or even positive. Now of course, we are aiming to make this happen in a very strong way; it depends on November-December.
Okay. Thank you very much for the patience...
I'm sorry to disappoint you that you take – I would like to see what you have written in March, can you send me your forecast for the half-year results of the group, please?
I will send it to you.
What was your forecast? Mr. Eifert, what was your forecast for our group?
EBIT was 310 million per year approximately.
And the rest, the turnover?
I expected a decline of 19% per year, so pricing as well.

So you took my comments not serious in March. You just told me that you give a shit on my comments on March. So do please the same today also. You will probably do it. So why are you spending my time and throwing my time out of the window? I will not talk with you anymore. So you just showed me that you give a shit on what the CEO of the group has said. Thank you very much.
Okay. Ladies and gentlemen, sorry for the tough words at the end, but sometimes the truth is hitting and it hurts. I wish you a very nice evening altogether. Bye-bye.
Ladies and gentlemen, the conference is now over. Thank you for choosing the conference call facility and thank you for participating in the conference. You may now disconnect your lines. Goodbye.
